text.tspan: Techniques for visualizing chaotic maps and similar systems are typically very simple- the system's states are mapped to pixels on
an image, and at each iteration the current state's pixel is darkened partially or completely. With this method, either the resulting
image is very low quality, or the system must run for a long time before any usable image is generated. This makes it difficult to
experiment with a system's parameters and render high quality images from them.
Our method treats the image as a two dimensional histogram, and divides the rendering process into two steps: collecting histogram
samples, and generating an image from the histogram. Like pixels in the traditional technique, each histogram bucket maps to a
range of states in the chaotic system. As the system iterates, the histogram buckets each sample the probability that the chaotic
system's state falls within its range of states. To create an image in the second step, the histogram buckets are mapped to pixels
and the probabilities are mapped to colors. Normally each bucket corresponds to one pixel, but oversampling may be implemented
by mapping multiple buckets to one pixel.
Unlike the traditional technique's images, these histograms will converge over time rather than diverge. This means that a crude
rendering can be generated very quickly, then progressively refined. As the histogram is refined, the relatively fast conversion from
histogram to image can be repeated, showing this refinement in real-time. The ability to show a complete but possibly low quality
image at any time gives this technique excellent interactivity, making it suitable as a tool for artists and everyday computer users to
explore chaotic maps. Current desktop computers can achieve very smooth interactivity in our implementation at modest image sizes.
Mapping Chaos
David Trowbridge
trowbrds@cs.colorado.edu
Micah Dowty
micah@navi.cx
Traditional Rendering
Histogram Rendering
SIGGRAPH 2004
Los Angeles, California
Clamped Before Interpolation
Clamped After Interpolation
The extra detail stored in the original high dynamic range histogram can also
be expressed with the help of color. We take an approach that mirrors the way
natural objects appear in photography. Very bright objects, for example, saturate
the image and always appear white. By clamping each color component as late
as possible in the rendering process, a similar saturation effect can be achieved:
The logistic map bifurcation diagram is an omnipresent image in the study of
chaotic maps. By using a histogram-based imaging technique to render it, a
striking amount of additional detail is uncovered.
The interactive properties of histogram rendering make it easy to find
appealing images and tweak them with an artistic eye rather than mathematics.
Background
Foreground
Colorspace
Background
Foreground
Colorspace
Increased Gamma
Decreased Exposure,
Increased Gamma
Base Image
Increased Exposure
The histogram data collected while iterating the chaotic system is treated as a
high dynamic range image. As is common with high dynamic range image
processing, we can perform gamma and exposure adjustment at the original
image's full precision, and use various settings to bring out different details in
the image. This is all done while converting the histogram to an image, so the
exposure, gamma adjustment, and colorization parameters can all be adjusted
in real-time without restarting any calculations. This makes it particularly easy
to explore the hidden details in a single histogram:
